comments.body:
Why did you add running benchmarks when the original issue was just to migrate `lint.sh` to Azure?  IMO, this should have been considered in a separate PR.

Also, as your changes did not actually modify any Python benchmark code, it was not possible to review how it would look in the Azure logs.  This log here from another PR (#23752) is unfortunately impossible to read:

https://dev.azure.com/pandas-dev/pandas/_build/results?buildId=4580

Also, it's somewhat debatable as to whether we even want to just run benchmarks when there's only a diff in `asv_bench`.  We often ask people to run `asv` whenever there are changes to C and Cython code in general, just to make sure that no benchmarks were affected as a result of the changes.

Hmm...IMO, I think running doctests should be a separate build entirely from linting.  They are two semantically different things, and the separation would allow us to provide more semantically clear display names such as "Doctests" and "Linting" instead of the slightly vaguer mashup of "Checks_and_doc".

I see there was a concern about not having to use an extra build for this due to resource constraints (the conversation is a very long in this PR...)?  However, I'm not sure I fully understand...

Also, based on the conversation, are the `master` docs no longer being published on https://pandas-docs.github.io/pandas-docs-travis?  In which case, we need to update the `GITHUB_ISSUE` template that we have [here](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/b7bdf7c/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md).

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +88,92 @@      ci/code_checks.sh doctests
    displayName: 'Running doctests'
    condition: true

  - script: |

comments.body: What environment file is this?
The one in the root, for dev environments (like locally). It's the one that contains the dependencies to build the docs.
Oh of course. Should we re-use `ci/deps/travis-36-doc.yaml` for now (and rename that when the travis doc job is removed)?

I thought travis was using `environment.yml`.

I'd personally use `environment.yml`, so we build in the CI with the same versions as locally, and remove `travis-36-doc.yaml` when we remove the travis job. Also it keep things simpler.

Any other advantage of using a specific dependencies file besides installing only the needed packages for the docs?

> besides installing only the needed packages for the docs?

I think that's the primary benefit, but it's not a big deal to install extra deps (like test-only ones).

Stepping back, my main request is that we use the same env for building the travis & azure docs. I don't have a strong preference for whether that's `/environment.yaml` or `ci/deps/travis-36-doc.yaml`.

+1 for same on each

+1 for environment.yml
That makes sense, I changed travis build to use `environment.yml` for the docs.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +125,129 @@  - script: |
      echo '##vso[task.setvariable variable=CONDA_ENV]pandas-dev'
      echo '##vso[task.setvariable variable=ENV_FILE]environment.yml'
    displayName: 'Setting environment variables'

comments.body: can you make it so if this job fails it won't fail the entire build? just so we don't replicate the same problem as last time

Doesn't seem like pipelines has a feature like the travis one for allowed failures.

I can make the `git push` step finish green even if it fails, I guess that's the closer option. But this time I set up the CI in my pandas fork, and made sure the part only executed after merging to master is able to push to dev.pandas.io, and it's working correctly.

Let me know if you want to be extra sure, but shouldn't happen the same as last time, the whole job is tested now.
right that's the part that could fail (as its only done on master); maybe not fail even if that fails

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +117,121 @@    condition: true

- job: 'Docs'
  pool:
    vmImage: ubuntu-16.04

comments.body: At some point you also had a pandas-dev-docs, that's removed again?

Yes, I started using that, but then I removed it. Using `<organization-name>.github.io` we're able to use directly a custom domain `dev.pandas.io`. Any other name of repo will make the url something like `dev.pandas.io/pandas-dev-docs`. Personally I think it'll be very nice to have `dev.pandas.io`, even more when we move to `pandas.io`. After almost two years working in the docs I still don't remember the url of the travis docs. :)
Okido, I am not fully sure about the final url, but that's a discussion for later :-)

      cd doc/build/html
      git remote add origin git@github.com:pandas-dev/pandas-dev.github.io.git
      git push -f origin master
      exit 0  # FIXME this will leave the build green even if the step fails. To be removed when we are confident with this.

Sorry, I apparently wasn't on master (so my grep didn't find it).

comments.body:
Do you know of a way to just do this for all PRs? I have a hunch that this wouldn't run now for backports but didn't see anything in the docs:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/yaml-schema?view=azure-devops&tabs=example%2Cparameter-schema#pr-trigger

Maybe just need to specify as *:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/build/triggers?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml#wildcards

Though I think it's a bug that we need this in the first place given this in the docs:

> A pull request trigger specifies which branches cause a pull request build to run. If you specify no pull request trigger, pull requests to any branch trigger a build
